hints_html: Start off by cross multiplying. Then integrate (you may want to use partial fractions to integrate). I hope you ate your Wheaties because this is a long one...
hints_latex:
Start off by cross multiplying. Then integrate (you may want to use
partial fractions to integrate). I hope you ate your Wheaties because
this is a long one...
hints_raw: Start off by cross multiplying. Then integrate (you may want to use partial fractions to integrate). I hope you ate your Wheaties because this is a long one...
question: 8 (a)
sols_html:
Cross multiplying our equation, we have that

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{(0.1 - x)(0.2-x)} \, dx = k \, dt\end{aligned}\]

Now we integrate. The right hand side integrates to

\[\begin{aligned} \int k \, dt = kt\end{aligned}\]

As for the left hand side, we integrate by partial fractions.

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{(0.1 - x)(0.2-x)} &= \frac{A}{(0.1-x)} + \frac{B}{(0.2-x)} \\ &= \frac{A(0.2-x) + B(0.1-x)}{(0.1 - x)(0.2-x)} \\ &= \frac{(-A-B)x + A(0.2) + B(0.1)}{(0.1 - x)(0.2-x)}\end{aligned}\]

Now we can either compare coefficients or plug in values for x. I will choose to plug in values for x. The above tells us that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle 1 = A(0.2-x) + B(0.1-x)\end{aligned}\]

when \(x = 0.2\), we have that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle 1 = A(0.2-0.2) + B(0.1-0.2) = B(-0.1)\end{aligned}\]

and so \(B = -10\). When \(x = 0.1\), we have

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle 1 = A(0.2-0.1) + B(0.1-0.1) = A(0.1)\end{aligned}\]

and so \(A = 10\). Hence, we have

\[\begin{aligned} \int \frac{1}{(0.1 - x)(0.2-x)} \, dx &= \int \frac{10}{(0.1-x)}\, dx - \int\frac{10}{(0.2-x)}\, dx \\ &= -10\ln|0.1-x| + 10\ln|0.2-x|.\end{aligned}\]

(technically the above should add a constant but we can include this in a minute.) Hence

\[\begin{aligned} \int \frac{1}{(0.1 - x)(0.2-x)} \, dx = \int k \, dt\end{aligned}\]

becomes

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle 10\ln|0.2-x| - 10\ln|0.1-x| = kt + C\end{aligned}\]

Using the initial condition of \(x(0) = 0\), we see that our constant is

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle 10\ln|0.2| - 10\ln|0.1| = C\end{aligned}\]

and simplifying, this becomes

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle C = 10(\ln\tfrac{0.2}{0.1}) = 10\ln(2)\end{aligned}\]

Our equation simplifies to

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle 10\ln \left|\frac{0.2-x}{0.1-x} \right| = 10\ln|0.2-x| - 10\ln|0.1-x| = kt +10\ln(2)\end{aligned}\]

Exponentiating the far left and the far right hand sides of the above gives

\[\begin{aligned} \left|\frac{0.2-x}{0.1-x} \right|^{10} = 2^{10}e^{kt}\end{aligned}\]

Taking the tenth root of both sides yields

\[\begin{aligned} \left|\frac{0.2-x}{0.1-x} \right| = 2e^{\tfrac{kt}{10}}\end{aligned}\]

Removing the absolute values, we have

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{0.2-x}{0.1-x} = \pm 2e^{\tfrac{kt}{10}}\end{aligned}\]

Plugging in the initial condition of \(x(0) = 0\), we see that only the positive value above works. Hence

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{0.2-x}{0.1-x} = 2e^{\tfrac{kt}{10}}\end{aligned}\]

Now, we cross multiply to see that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle 0.2-x = 2e^{\tfrac{kt}{10}}(0.1-x) = 0.2e^{\tfrac{kt}{10}} -x(2e^{\tfrac{kt}{10}})\end{aligned}\]

Bringing the \(x\) values to one side gives

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle x(2e^{\tfrac{kt}{10}})-x = 0.2e^{\tfrac{kt}{10}} -0.2\end{aligned}\]

Lastly, isolating for \(x\) gives

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle x = \frac{0.2e^{\tfrac{kt}{10}} -0.2 }{2e^{\tfrac{kt}{10}} - 1}\end{aligned}\]

completing the question.
sols_raw:
Cross multiplying our equation, we have that

:<math>
\frac{1}{(0.1 - x)(0.2-x)} \, dx = k \, dt
</math>

Now we integrate. The right hand side integrates to

:<math>
\int k \, dt = kt
</math>

As for the left hand side, we integrate by partial fractions.

:<math>
\begin{align}
\frac{1}{(0.1 - x)(0.2-x)}  &= \frac{A}{(0.1-x)} + \frac{B}{(0.2-x)} \\
&= \frac{A(0.2-x) + B(0.1-x)}{(0.1 - x)(0.2-x)} \\
&= \frac{(-A-B)x + A(0.2) + B(0.1)}{(0.1 - x)(0.2-x)}
\end{align}
</math>

Now we can either compare coefficients or plug in values for ''x''. I will choose to plug in values for ''x''. The above tells us that

:<math> \displaystyle
1 = A(0.2-x) + B(0.1-x)
</math>

when <math> x = 0.2 </math>, we have that

:<math> \displaystyle
1 =  A(0.2-0.2) + B(0.1-0.2) = B(-0.1)
</math>

and so <math> B = -10 </math>. When <math> x = 0.1 </math>, we have

:<math> \displaystyle
1 =  A(0.2-0.1) + B(0.1-0.1) = A(0.1)
</math>

and so <math> A = 10 </math>. Hence, we have

:<math> 
\begin{align}
\int \frac{1}{(0.1 - x)(0.2-x)} \, dx &= \int \frac{10}{(0.1-x)}\, dx - \int\frac{10}{(0.2-x)}\, dx \\
&= -10\ln|0.1-x| + 10\ln|0.2-x|.
\end{align}
</math>

(technically the above should add a constant but we can include this in a minute.) Hence

:<math>
\int \frac{1}{(0.1 - x)(0.2-x)} \, dx = \int k \, dt
</math>

becomes

:<math> \displaystyle
10\ln|0.2-x| - 10\ln|0.1-x| = kt + C
</math>

Using the initial condition of <math> x(0) = 0 </math>, we see that our constant is

:<math> \displaystyle
10\ln|0.2| - 10\ln|0.1| = C
</math>

and simplifying, this becomes

:<math> \displaystyle
C = 10(\ln\tfrac{0.2}{0.1}) = 10\ln(2)
</math>

Our equation simplifies to

:<math> \displaystyle
10\ln \left|\frac{0.2-x}{0.1-x} \right| = 10\ln|0.2-x| - 10\ln|0.1-x| = kt +10\ln(2)
</math>

Exponentiating the far left and the far right hand sides of the above gives

:<math>
\left|\frac{0.2-x}{0.1-x} \right|^{10}  = 2^{10}e^{kt}
</math>

Taking the tenth root of both sides yields

:<math>
\left|\frac{0.2-x}{0.1-x} \right|  = 2e^{\tfrac{kt}{10}}
</math>

Removing the absolute values, we have

:<math>
\frac{0.2-x}{0.1-x}  = \pm 2e^{\tfrac{kt}{10}}
</math>

Plugging in the initial condition of <math> x(0) = 0 </math>, we see that only the positive value above works. Hence

:<math>
\frac{0.2-x}{0.1-x}  = 2e^{\tfrac{kt}{10}} 
</math>

Now, we cross multiply to see that

:<math> \displaystyle
0.2-x = 2e^{\tfrac{kt}{10}}(0.1-x) = 0.2e^{\tfrac{kt}{10}} -x(2e^{\tfrac{kt}{10}})
</math>

Bringing the <math> x </math> values to one side gives

:<math> \displaystyle
x(2e^{\tfrac{kt}{10}})-x = 0.2e^{\tfrac{kt}{10}} -0.2
</math>

Lastly, isolating for <math> x </math> gives

:<math> \displaystyle
x = \frac{0.2e^{\tfrac{kt}{10}} -0.2 }{2e^{\tfrac{kt}{10}} - 1}
</math>

completing the question.
statement_html:
Consider the chemical reaction

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle A + B \rightarrow C + D.\end{aligned}\]

Suppose at time t = 0 sec the concentration of chemical A is 0.1 mol/L, the concentration of chemical B is 0.2 mol/L, and the concentrations of chemicals C and D are both 0. For t \(\geq\) 0, let x(t) be the concentration of chemical D in mol/L. It can be shown that x(t) is the solution to the initial-value problem

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dx}{dt} = k(0.1-x)(0.2-x), \quad x(0)=0,\end{aligned}\]

where k is a positive constant whole value can be determined by experiment.

(a) Solve the initial-value problem to find x(t) explicitly.
statement_raw:
Consider the chemical reaction

:<math>\displaystyle
A + B \rightarrow C + D.
</math>

Suppose at time ''t'' = 0 sec the concentration of chemical ''A'' is 0.1 mol/L, the concentration of chemical ''B'' is 0.2 mol/L, and the concentrations of chemicals ''C'' and ''D'' are both 0. For ''t'' &ge; 0, let ''x(t)'' be the concentration of chemical ''D'' in mol/L. It can be shown that ''x(t)'' is the solution to the initial-value problem

:<math>
\frac{dx}{dt} = k(0.1-x)(0.2-x), \quad x(0)=0,
</math>

where ''k'' is a positive constant whole value can be determined by experiment.

:(a) Solve the initial-value problem to find ''x(t)'' explicitly.
